definition: The superior portion of the abdominopelvic cavity, containing organs such as the stomach, liver, gallbladder, pancreas, spleen, small intestine, kidneys, appendix, and part of the large intestine.
Consists of two continuous cavities: the abdominal cavity and the pelvic cavity.
The division of the abdominopelvic cavity into four quadrants formed by transverse and sagittal planes running through the umbilicus (navel).
The division of the abdominopelvic cavity into nine regions using two vertical and two horizontal lines, forming a tic-tac-toe grid to locate organs.
Spaces within the body that contain vital organs. The major body cavities are the cranial cavity, thoracic cavity, and abdominopelvic cavity.

Transports nutrients, chemical messengers, gases, and wastes in blood.
Major organs: heart and blood vessels
The cavity that contains the brain and is continuous with the vertebral canal that contains the spinal cord.
A muscle that separates the thoracic cavity from the abdominopelvic cavity.

Breaks down food into units that can be absorbed into the blood; eliminates wastes and non-digestible fiber in food.
Major organs: mouth, salivary glands, pharynx, esophagus, stomach, intestines, pancreas, liver, gallbladder

Controls cell function with hormones; helps control body homeostasis.
Major organs: hypothalamus, pituitary gland, pineal gland, thymus, thyroid gland, pancreas, adrenal glands, ovaries, testes
The upper central region of the abdominopelvic cavity, above the stomach.
The lower central region of the abdominopelvic cavity, below the stomach.

Provides a protective barrier for the body and aids in production of vitamin D; eliminates some waste; contains sensory receptors for pain, touch, and temperature; fat provides insulation.
Major organs: skin and skin structures (hair, nails, sweat glands, oil glands)
The upper left region of the abdominopelvic cavity, beneath the ribs.
The lower left region of the abdominopelvic cavity, near the groin.
The middle left region of the abdominopelvic cavity, near the loins.
The lower left quadrant of the abdominopelvic cavity.
The upper left quadrant of the abdominopelvic cavity.

Returns fluid to blood; carries dietary lipids from GI tract to blood; detects and eliminates disease-causing organisms.
Major organs: lymphatic vessels, lymph nodes, spleen, thymus, bone marrow, tonsils

A central area within the thoracic cavity that extends from the neck to the diaphragm and from the sternum to the vertebral column. It contains the heart, thymus gland, esophagus, trachea, blood vessels, and bronchi.

Moves bones and maintains posture; major source of body heat.
Major organs: skeletal muscles and tendons

Controls cell function with electrical signals; helps control body homeostasis.
Major organs: brain, spinal cord, nerves, and special sense organs
The layer of the serous membrane that attaches to and covers the ventral body wall.
The inferior portion of the abdominopelvic cavity that contains part of the large intestine, rectum, urinary bladder, and reproductive organs.
A small cavity within the thoracic cavity that surrounds the heart.
The cavity within the abdominal cavity that contains most abdominal organs.
The serous membrane that covers abdominal organs in the peritoneal cavity.
Two cavities within the thoracic cavity that each contain a lung.

Produces gametes and sex hormones; female uterus provides environment for development of fetus.
Major organs in male: testes, ductus deferens, penis
Major organs in female: ovaries, uterine tubes, uterus, vagina

Adds oxygen to blood and removes carbon dioxide from blood; produces sound; maintains body fluid pH.
Major organs: nose, pharynx (throat), larynx, trachea, bronchi, lungs
Refers to organs located posterior to the peritoneum, including the pancreas, kidneys, adrenal glands, and portions of the large intestine.
The upper right region of the abdominopelvic cavity, beneath the ribs.
The lower right region of the abdominopelvic cavity, near the groin.
The middle right region of the abdominopelvic cavity, near the loins.
The lower right quadrant of the abdominopelvic cavity.
The upper right quadrant of the abdominopelvic cavity.
A clear, watery fluid that prevents friction as the organs move within the ventral body cavity.

Thin, clear, watery fluid membranes composed of two layers: a visceral layer that covers the organ and a parietal layer that attaches to and covers the ventral body wall. These two layers form one continuous sheet that folds to form a sac.

Protects major organs; provides levers and support for body movement; bone marrow contains stem cells that produce blood cells, and is site for maturation of lymphocytes.
Major organs: bones and cartilage
A space enclosed by the ribs, sternum, and vertebral column. It contains the pericardial cavity and two pleural cavities.
Includes the pleura (covering the lungs) and the pericardium (covering the heart).
The central region of the abdominopelvic cavity, surrounding the navel.
The layer of the serous membrane that covers the organ.

Removes nitrogenous wastes; maintains body fluid volume, pH, and electrolyte levels through urine production.
Major organs: kidneys, ureters, urinary bladder, urethra
